maml:description.maml:para: Convert SDDL string to Principal
Convert one or multiple SDDL strings to Principal, a custom object containing relevant information about the principal.
One or more strings of SDDL syntax

If specified, does not perform name checking of converted string. This is useful for example to force spliting name like: "NT APPLICATION PACKAGE AUTHORITY\Your Internet connection, including incoming connections from the Internet"
One or more strings of SDDL syntax

If specified, does not perform name checking of converted string. This is useful for example to force spliting name like: "NT APPLICATION PACKAGE AUTHORITY\Your Internet connection, including incoming connections from the Internet"
Convert SID to principal, user and domain name

Convert SID to principal, user and domain name, in case of pseudo and built in accounts only relevant login name is returned, not full reference name. In all other cases result if full account name in form of COMPUTERNAME\USERNAME
One or more SIDs to convert
One or more computers to check if SID is not known, the default is localhost
One or more SIDs to convert
One or more computers to check if SID is not known, the default is localhost

maml:alert.maml:para: To avoid confusion, pseudo accounts ("Local Service" in the example below) can be represented as: 1. SID (S-1-5-19) 2. Name (NT AUTHORITY) 3. Reference Name (NT AUTHORITY\Local Service) 4. Display Name (Local Service)

On the other side built in accounts ("Administrator" in the example below) can be represented as: 1. SID (S-1-5-21-500) 2. Name (Administrator) 3. Reference Name (BUILTIN\Administrator) 4. Display Name (Administrator)

This is important to understand because MSDN site (links in comment) just says "Name", but we can't just use given "Name" value to refer to user when defining rules because it's not valid for multiple reasons such as: 1. There are duplicate names, which SID do you want if "Name" is duplicate? 2. Some "names" are not login usernames or accounts, but we need either username or account 3. Some "names" are NULL, such as capability SID's See also: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/identity-protection/access-control/security-identifiers
To solve this problem "Name" must be replaced with "Display Name", most "Name" values are OK, but those which are not are replaced with "Display Name" in the "WellKnownSIDs" switch below.

TODO: Need to implement switch parameters for UPN and NETBIOS name format in addition to display name, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/secauthn/user-name-formats TODO: Need to have consistent output ex. domain name, principal and username, see test results, probably not for pseudo accounts but for built in accounts it makes sense TODO: Need to implement CIM switch TODO: Test pipeline with multiple computers and SID's, probably it make no sense for multiple targets

maml:description.maml:para: Get principals of specified groups on target computers
Get computer accounts for one or more user groups on local computer or one or more remote computers.
User group on local or remote computer
One or more computers which to query for group users
Specifies a username as a wildcard pattern that this function includes in the operation.
Specifies a username as a wildcard pattern that this function excludes from operation.
If specified, result is disabled accounts instead
Whether to contact CIM server (required for remote computers)
User group on local or remote computer
One or more computers which to query for group users
Specifies a username as a wildcard pattern that this function includes in the operation.
Specifies a username as a wildcard pattern that this function excludes from operation.
If specified, result is disabled accounts instead
Whether to contact CIM server (required for remote computers)

maml:description.maml:para: Split principal to either user name or domain
Split either UPN or NETBIOS principal name to user name or domain name.
One or more principals in form of UPN or NetBIOS Name.
If specified, the result is domain name instead of user name
If specified, does not perform name checking
One or more principals in form of UPN or NetBIOS Name.
If specified, the result is domain name instead of user name
If specified, does not perform name checking
Takes a PSCredential object and validates it
Takes a PSCredential object and validates it against a domain or local machine
A PSCredential object with the username/password which is to be tested. Typically this is generated using the Get-Credential cmdlet.

Specifies the type of store to which the principal belongs: Domain: The domain store. This represents the AD DS store. Machine: The computer store. This represents the SAM store. ApplicationDirectory: The application directory store. This represents the AD LDS store.
Target computer against which to test local credential object
A PSCredential object with the username/password which is to be tested. Typically this is generated using the Get-Credential cmdlet.

Specifies the type of store to which the principal belongs: Domain: The domain store. This represents the AD DS store. Machine: The computer store. This represents the SAM store. ApplicationDirectory: The application directory store. This represents the AD LDS store.
Target computer against which to test local credential object

dev:type.maml:name: [bool] true if the credentials are valid, otherwise false

maml:alert.maml:para: Modifications by metablaster January 2021: Function interface reworked by removing unnecesarry parameter and changin param block Simplified logic to validate credential based on context type Added links, inputs, outputs and notes to comment based help TODO: Does not seem to work on LAN, try with Domain\User + pwd and: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/windows-firewall/create-inbound-rules-to-support-rpc

maml:description.maml:para: Validate Universal Principal Name syntax
Test if Universal Principal Name (UPN) has valid syntax. UPN consists of user account name, also known as the logon name and UPN suffix, also known as the domain name. (or an IP address)
Universal Principal Name in form of: user@domain.com If -Prefix is specified, domain name can be omitted. If -Suffix is specified, logon name can be omitted.
If specified, validate only the user name portion of a User Principal Name
If specified, UPN syntax errors are not shown, only true or false is returned.
Universal Principal Name in form of: user@domain.com If -Prefix is specified, domain name can be omitted. If -Suffix is specified, logon name can be omitted.
If specified, validate only the domain name portion of a User Principal Name
If specified, UPN syntax errors are not shown, only true or false is returned.
Universal Principal Name in form of: user@domain.com If -Prefix is specified, domain name can be omitted. If -Suffix is specified, logon name can be omitted.
If specified, validate only the user name portion of a User Principal Name
If specified, validate only the domain name portion of a User Principal Name
If specified, UPN syntax errors are not shown, only true or false is returned.

maml:alert.maml:para: User Principal Name (UPN) A user account name (sometimes referred to as the user logon name) and a domain name identifying the domain in which the user account is located. This is the standard usage for logging on to a Windows domain. The format is: someone@example.com (as for an email address). TODO: There is a thing such as: "MicrosoftAccount\TestUser@domain.com"
